title: Kip Anderson
text:
Kipling Taquana Anderson (January 24, 1938 – August 29, 2007), known professionally as Kip Anderson, was an American <a href="soul%20blues">soul blues</a> and <a href="Rhythm%20and%20blues">R&B</a> <a href="singing">singer</a> and <a href="songwriter">songwriter</a>. He is best known for his 1967 <a href="Single%20%28music%29">single</a>, "A Knife and a Fork". He recorded for many <a href="record%20label">record label</a>s, worked as a <a href="radio%20station">radio</a> <a href="Disc%20jockey">DJ</a>, and maintained a career lasting from the late 1950s to the 1990s, despite serving a decade-long custodial sentence. At various times Anderson worked with <a href="Sam%20Cooke">Sam Cooke</a>, the <a href="The%20Drifters">Drifters</a>, <a href="Jerry%20Butler%20%28singer%29">Jerry Butler</a> and <a href="Jackie%20Wilson">Jackie Wilson</a>.
Biography.
He was born Kipling Taquana Anderson in <a href="Starr%2C%20South%20Carolina">Starr</a>, <a href="Anderson%20County%2C%20South%20Carolina">Anderson County</a>, <a href="South%20Carolina">South Carolina</a>.
Anderson had his first musical exposure in church, where he sang and played the <a href="piano">piano</a>. After featuring in his high school band, Anderson met his future business partner, Charles Derrick, at radio station <a href="WISW">WOIC</a>, in <a href="Columbia%2C%20South%20Carolina">Columbia</a>. In 1959, Anderson's debut single, "I Wanna Be the Only One", was released by <a href="Vee-Jay%20Records">Vee-Jay Records</a>. For his follow-up release, "Oh My Linda", he was accompanied by the guitarist <a href="Mickey%20Baker">Mickey Baker</a>. Lack of commercial gains from recording led Anderson to find work as a disc jockey.
Everlast Records released Anderson's third single, "I Will Cry" (1962), and "Here I Am, Try Me", and "That's When the Crying Begins" (1964) followed; the latter reached number 79 on the <a href="Billboard%20Hot%20100">"Billboard" Hot 100</a>. His stock rose further with "I'll Get Along", "Woman How Do You Make Me Love You Like I Do", and "Without a Woman" (1966).
In 1967, Anderson released "A Knife and a Fork" for <a href="Checker%20Records">Checker</a>, <a href="sound%20recording%20and%20reproduction">recorded</a> at FAME Studios in <a href="Alabama">Alabama</a>. "A Knife and a Fork" was a midtempo warning to his girlfriend about her consumption of food: "girl, you gonna let a knife and a fork dig your grave". The single entered the "<a href="Billboard%20%28magazine%29">Billboard</a>" <a href="Hot%20R%26amp%3BB/Hip-Hop%20Songs">R&B</a> <a href="record%20chart">chart</a>. A follow-up release, "You'll Lose a Good Thing", issued by <a href="Excello%20Records">Excello Records</a>, also made the <a href="Top%2040">Top 40</a> on the R&B chart. "I Went Off and Cried" (1968) may be his best-remembered recording, next to "A Knife and a Fork". A <a href="cover%20version">cover version</a> of "A Knife and a Fork" was recorded by <a href="Rockpile">Rockpile</a> for the 1980 album "<a href="Seconds%20of%20Pleasure">Seconds of Pleasure</a>".
A dependency on heroin started to affect his work by 1970, and Excello cancelled his <a href="recording%20contract">recording contract</a>. he continued to record and perform in the 1970s, but a ten-year prison sentence in 1974 for possession of heroin halted his activities. He later stated, "It probably saved my life." While in prison he formed a gospel group with other inmates, who performed under surveillance at local churches and community events.
Upon his release from prison, Anderson recorded a <a href="gospel%20music">gospel</a> <a href="album">album</a>, before issuing more soul-based music for <a href="Ichiban%20Records">Ichiban Records</a>. He also revived his career as a DJ when he moved back to Anderson County. He also hosted a gospel show on <a href="WHQA">WRIX-FM</a> and served as vice president of Electric City Record's gospel division. In 1996, Anderson duetted with <a href="Nappy%20Brown">Nappy Brown</a> on the "Best of Both Worlds" joint album.
Anderson died in <a href="Anderson%2C%20South%20Carolina">Anderson, South Carolina</a>, in August 2007, at the age of 69.
